bibl.title: Hisayo Kuwahara v. Henry M. White. Petition
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: The District Court of the United States, Western District of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: In the United States District Court for the Western District of Washington
In the Matter of the Petition of Sakutaro Kuwahara for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.
Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus
Filed in the United States District Court
Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus.
In the Matter of the Petition of Sakutaro Kuwahara for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.
To the Honorable, the Judge of the above entitled Court:
The petition of Sakutaro Kuwahara respectfully represents as follows:

That he came to the United States of America as a stowaway and without examination by Immigration officers of the United States or any formalities whatsoever in the Immigration office of the United States in the month of October, 1913, and has ever since lived in the United States and has not been during said period outside the limits of the United States, and since the 10th day of December, 1914,he has resided at Eatonville, in the County of Pierce, State of Washington, and is now a resident of said Eatonville.
That before leaving the Empire of Japan, your petitioner was lawfully married to Hisayo Kuwahara, and your petitioner and said Hisayo Kuwahara have ever since been and now are husband and wife.

That on the 27th of September, 1919, the aforesaid wife of your petitioner, Hisayo Kuwahara, arrived at the Port of Seattle on board the steamship Africa Maru, and on the 3rd day of October, 1919, the United States Commissioner of Immigration at the Port of Seattle, after an examination of your petitioner's aforesaid wife, Hisayo Kuwahara,excluded her from admission to the United States; and thereafter an appeal was duly taken from said decision to the Secretary of Labor, who on the 15th day of January, 1920,dismissed, refused and denied said appeal.

That the aforesaid wife of you petitioner, Hisayo Kuwahara, is now in the custody of Henry M.White, Commissioner of Immigration of the United States of America, at the Port of Seattle, and detained in the Immigration Station maintained by the United States at said Port of Seattle, and the said Henry M.White, as Commissioner aforesaid, will within a few days deport your petitioner's aforesaid wife. Hisayo
That the Board of Special Inquiry which passed upon the entry of Hisayo Kuwahara was not constituted according to law and hence without authority to pass thereon.

That your petitioner is abundantly able and is ready and willing and anxious to support his aforesaid wife, Hisayo Kuwahara, and is able to make a good home for his aforesaid wife, and your petitioner intends to remain in the United States, and is and has been for more than five years last past employed in a saw mill at Eatonville, aforesaid.

WHEREFORE, Your petitioner prays that a writ of Habeas Corpus may issue herein to the said Henry M.White, United States Commissioner, aforesaid, commanding him that he do produce the said Hisayo Kuwahara before this Court, together with the cause of her detention, and that upon the hearing the aforesaid Hisayo Kuwahara be discharged and permitted to land and be admitted into the United States of America, and for such other and further relief as to the Court may seem meet in the premises.
to the Secretary of Labor, who on the 15th day of January, 1920,dismissed, refused and denied said appeal.

That the aforesaid wife of your petitioner, Hisayo Kuwahara, is now in the custody of Henry M.White, Commissioner of Immigration of the United States of America, at the Port of Seattle, and detained in the Immigration Station maintained by the United States at said Port of Seattle, and the said Henry M.White, as Commissioner aforesaid, will within a few days deport your petitioner's aforesaid wife, Hisayo Kuwahara,and return her to the said Empire of Japan.

That the reason and ground assigned by the aforesaid Commissioner of Immigration for the exclusion of the aforesaid wife of your petitioner, Hisayo Kuwahara, and the only ground assigned therefor was because your petitioner landed in the United States as a stowaway without examination or admission by any Immigration authorities of the United States.

That your petitioner is abundantly able and is ready and willing and anxious to support his aforesaid wife, Hisayo Kuwahara, and is able to make a good home for his aforesaid wife, Hisayo Kuwahara, and is able to make a good home for his aforesaid wife, and your petitioner intends to remain in the United States, and is and has been for more than five years last past employed in a saw mill at Eatonville, aforesaid.

WHEREFORE, Your petitioner prays that a writ of Habeas Corpus may issue herein to the said Henry M.White, United States Commissioner, aforesaid, commanding him that he do produce the said Hisayo Kuwahara before this Court, together with the cause of her detention, and that upon the hearing the aforesaid Hisayo Kuwahara be discharged and permitted to land and be admitted into the United States of America, and for such other and further relief as to the Court may seem meet in the premises.

Sakutaro Kuwahara being first duly sworn according to law deposes and says; That he is the petitioner above-named; That he has heard read the foregoing petition, knows the contents thereof and believes the facts therein stated to be true.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 21st day of January, 1920.
Notary Public in and for the State of Washington, residing at Seattle.
